Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of Citizenship Judge's decision on residency requirements
Application_Facts: Applicant provided evidence of 1099 days of physical presence but had undeclared absences and inconsistent documentation
Decision_Outcome: Decision found unreasonable due to lack of adequate reasoning
Court_Ruling: Appeal granted; case remanded for re-determination by a new decision-maker
Defendant_Behavior: Failure to declare all absences and provide consistent documentation
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged failure to meet 1095-day physical presence requirement
Assessment_Factor: Physical presence in Canada over four years
Credibility_Assessment: Inconsistent documentation and lack of explanation for absences
Evidence_Used: Records of Ms. Hussein's presence in Canada
Application_Basis: Requirement of at least 1095 days of physical presence in Canada
Evidence_Assessed: Documentation of residency and travel history
Relief_Sought: Granting of appeal and remand for redetermination
Governing_Rule: Applicants must be physically present in Canada for at least 1095 days within four years
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Undeclared absences and inconsistencies in supporting documents
Harm_Assessment: Unjustified denial of citizenship due to inadequate reasoning
Cause_Description: Rejection of citizenship application due to alleged failure to meet residency requirements
Evidence_Handling: Judge failed to adequately explain how evidence was assessed or discounted
Evidence_Issues: Inconsistencies and lack of clarity in residency records
Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal jurisdiction under Citizenship Act and Federal Courts Act
Evidence_Assessment: Insufficient explanation by judge regarding credibility and weight of evidence
Decision_Rationale: Lack of transparent and justifiable reasoning in rejecting the application
Evidentiary_Issues: Incomplete disclosure of absences, inconsistent documentation
